Inspired by the Star Trek episode where Kirk fights the Gorn, Mythbusters tested whether a useful mix could be made without precise tools like your gram scale.

Spoiler Alert:
Nope.

It should be noted that gunpowder based on this formula was rendered obsolete in 1886 with the invention of "smokeless" powder, also called nitrocellulose. Although not truly smokeless nitrocellulose does emit only a tiny fraction of the smoke of traditional black powder, burns much faster, leaves less residue, and the residue it does leave isn't inherently corrosive like black powder residue. As a result nearly every firearm designed after 1886 has been completely dependant on nitrocellulose to function. Putting black powder in a gun designed for smokeless will gunk up the gun within a relatively small number of shots, cause it not to cycle if any energy from the shot is used to move internal parts (like in semi-automatic or fully-automatic guns), and begin corroding the gun if it isn't cleaned promptly. On the other hand putting smokeless in a gun designed for black powder can blow up the gun.

Put it all into a pile at least five times bigger than yours and ground it together on a metal cookie sheet in the basement.

You probably see where this is going.

A small corner ignited, and the entire pile went-up in a brilliant nano-second. A mushroom cloud rolled up and along the ceiling, then up the basement stairs into the house. Black Powder is most cool. AND you can make it at home. KNO3 75%, 10% Sulfur, and 15% Charcoal wet blended in any blender with Isopropanol. Push the mud thru a window screen and air dried. The finer grind the better performance. Combine Sulfur and Char Coal (Soft Wood Char coal works best) with Sulfur. Blend dry until super fine. Set aside. Wet Blend KNO3 wetted with Isopropanol Alcohol until super fine. Combine both WET and Blend until SUPER FINE MUD. Sun Dry until somewhat like mud. Force thru some window screen to granulate. Allow to fully dry. You have something like 3F Black Powder. This stuff can HURT YOU.

Your powder burns only very slowly because it needs to be dampened, dried and re-ground in a process called "corning". This is where the commercial stuff really differs and disappears in a flash. This has the effect of allowing the potassium nitrate oxidizer to far more intimately connect with the fuel and it creates grains which burn much faster than fine powder.

Wow. Really? Congrats you just made MEAL POWDER not, repeat NOT BLACK powder. This is the stuff Europeans mixed up on the battlefields just prior to loaded...before “corned” powder was discovered. The latter being more consolidated/mixed better and also allowing more air between the larger “corns” of powder. This gave better ignition and burn rates, NOT “explosions”. This is a propellant. Also, never pack any powder...it may not ignite correctly, just fizzle or burn like a weak rocket. The Chinese made use of this and called their first firearms “firelances” because they shot out burning pieces of charcoal sparks scaring the enemy.
You’re using dusting sulfur which contains a surgical tip which should be washed off before using.

Hold up there. Charcoal is NOT just “carbon”. If you use pure carbon you’ll be disappointed in the results. Charcoal is C7H4O. And your charcoal must be made of a soft, knot-free wood with no resins. Black willow and alder are best. Retort it till flame goes out and bury can for 24 hours. This dark brown charcoal is the most important ingredient of the three.

When I was in High School I had access to the chemistry supply room.  I used the same ingredients finding that plain charcoal briquest worked about the best for the charcoal, though there wasn't that much difference between anything I tested as long as it was completely burnt.  I did a 1-1-1 mix.  Worked just fine.  Burnt fast and pretty bright.  Later, I mixed it with enough water to make a paste.  I stirred it well and spread it out to air dry.  About a day later, I had some VERY nice crystals of gun powder.  It wasn't really black, more of a dark grey but it really had a nice sparkle to it.  When I set it off, it didn't really burn faster, but it was hotter and VERY bright!  It was white light bright.

One step is missing.
Medieval BP tended to separate out with time and vibration ( ie, shaking in cart-loads, movement, etc.
This was fixed by " Corning"...the mixture was wetted with water, or moreoften, Urine. The wet mess was the pressed into round cakes like Cheeses.
Once dried, the cakes were broken--
up with woodenrollers against wooden plates. As the resulting grains grewfiner, the powder was seived out into several sizes, from coarse ( cannon grade) to medium ( musket) to fine ( pistol grade) to very fine or dust( priming grade).
All utensils were made of wood or brass ( non sparking) and no heavy pressure was used ( BP is impact sensitive!!!).
BTW, in the Renaissance, Urine from youngvirgins and Priests was preferred, for its sanctifying properties.!!!! ( probably because it wasn't contaminated by loose living or disease.).
Later, a mixture of alcohol and water served the corning process, and dried more quickly.

Mixing with a straw and shaking really doesn't incorporate the components very well, hence the slow burn rate.  The best method of mixing black powder is with a ball mill. *Firecrackers and exploding fireworks in general are NOT made with black powder. They are produced with "flash powder", which is more powerful and more sensitive(and therefore more dangerous), depending on which 'recipe' you choose, AND the consistency the final product. I've never made any myself, but as a chemistry buff, I've read about it.*

The most common recipe for flash powder used in commercial firecrackers, is aluminum powder and potassium chlorate. However, the use of potassium chlorate as an oxidizer, is potentially more dangerous, because it creates a more friction sensitive flash powder than can be set off accidentally, by stirring the powder too hard! But it can be made in a safer, less sensitive form, by using the 'perchlorate' form of the chemical, instead of chlorate. So a mixture of aluminum powder and potassium perchlorate is supposed to be significantly safer.

Also, producing it in the form of extremely fine powder is NOT the most efficient and most powerful form, because it burns slower, which is the opposite of what you want in an effective flash powder. The mixture will burn faster and more efficiently when the particles are larger, with air spaces in between the particles. Some people go as far as to produce specifically shaped particles.

But there are other recipes for flash powder, that utilize magnesium powder in place of powdered aluminum, and sodium nitrate in place of potassium perchlorate. Depending on final particle size and shape, as well as chemical ratio, you can end up with a flash powder that burns so fast and efficiently, that it practically detonates in open air, even when not confined inside a closed airtight container! It behaves more like a high explosive than a low explosive like black powder!

Real granulated black powder burns much faster than the fine powder version you just made.   Real black powder burns at the same rate whether it is compressed or not.   Modern smokeless nitrocellulose based powder burns slowly when unconfined.  When it is confined, it burns progressively faster as the pressure increases.  Both types of powder create their own oxygen......that is why they burn when confined.  Most fuels, including gasoline will not burn by themselves.  They must have oxygen present to combust.

You can refine that powder by mixing it with pure ethanol and boiling it down until moist, take it off the heat and let it cool a bit, scoop it out and press it into a ball and scrape the ball over a metal sieve or window screen. The sulfur and salt petre melt and are absorbed into the charcoal powder's pores. When the remaining alcohol evaporates, the reaction will be much more intense!

Be sure to scrap the sides of the pot down while boiling and take it off the heat while there's still a bit of liquid left.

It will burn faster if you take your powder, spread it on a tray, wet it slowly by misting water through a spray bottle and knead it gently with your hands (with gloves on!). When it clumps together like wet sand you have enough water. Then take a handful at a time and grate it through some course mesh (like a fly screen). Leave the grated clumps to dry then break up any large clumps with the edge of a credit card. NOW you will have black powder!

Grant!  If you want REAL gunpowder, mix your powder with a little water, make a putty like slurry, grind the wet slurry with a WOODEN mortar and pestle and spread it out thin to dry on a sheet. When it dries, crush it gently to small particles, and light it again. It will burn 10 TIMES as fast!! That process coats each KNO3 crystal with carbon particles and sulfur particles, making the interaction more vigorous. It will go POOF into the air with a slight whump noise.

You have to wet it and granulate it. What you made is just the mill meal. Add 5% dextrin to it, and wet it so that it gets damp, and run it through your screen again. If it recombines coming through the screen, it's too wet, it should extrude in lines. Then lay it out and dry it, now you have gunpowder.

that recipe wasnt used by the chinese, not even remotely close, chinese black powder was very poorly suited for ballistic applications.. sulfur was added more recently to lower the ignition temperature to increase the reliability of flintlock rifles

also, black powder is generally mixed wet, then dried and reground to a specified size, this allows the liquid to absorb the potassium nitrate and as it dries it impregnates the porous charcoal with the other chemicals, its then granulated to generally FFg grade for rifles or FFFg for pistons, or very fine FFFFg for priming pans

What you are doing is called "dry mixing". It is the primitive way of mixing the ingredients together. You are basically making the old gunpowder that didn't work as well as it could. You could make "corned gunpowder" which is more powerful. You can make this by simply adding water into the mix (after crushing everything of course) until it becomes a bit like a slush, then let it dry. Very simple. This is NOT black powder, you can tell especially by how slow that burned. This is called green mix, which is a rough mixture of black powder ingredients without processing. To make black powder you must process green mix through milling, compression or corning. Black powder works by the sulfur and KNO3 being worked into the granules of charcoal on a microscopic level. Depending on how this is processed it may still be simple BP and not gunpowder. Simple BP packs together and therefore loses surface area and burns "slowly" unless compressed, it is used in pyrotechnics, rockets and some traditional black powder muzzle loaders but will not burn as fast as gunpowder when uncompressed. Traditional gunpowder is granulated in various grain sizes so that it has high surface area and burns much faster so that it can be used in firearms.

I can see not wanting to teach people how to make real black powder but you should probably specify what is being made for the sake of scientific accuracy.

I have done a fair bit of amateur pyrotechnics and rocketry work so feel free to hit me up if you have any questions.

I have that same brand of sulfur (Hi-yield) and noticed its only 90% pure. One option is to recrystalize the sufur but that requires some uncommon and expensive solvents. Instead I chose to boil the sulfur in a pot of water in order to raise the solubility of the impurities. My idea was that some of the impurities might desolve in water (with water coined as the universal solvent) and afterwards I could strain the sulfur from the hot water solution and in theory any of the said impurities that are soluble in water would be gone. I did this whole process before making a batch of black powder and did notice that after burning, there was less residue left behind as the reaction was more complete than that of using only 90% pure sulfur.

Hi Grant, if you would like your black powder to burn from a whoosh to a poof, could possibly try the following:
- Use a ball mill with lead grinding media. Ballmill the black power (all three chemicals together) for at least 12hrs. A ball mill really is the secrete to producing amazing black powder.
- Use 'willow' or 'balsa' wood charcoal instead of the paint sticks, you will get an increased burn rate. Charcoal makes a big difference.

Making a ball mill could be a project idea for your channel to follow on with your black powder adventures.

First off:
For charcoal, use wood from hardwood, like birch, not from spruce or pine. It burns faster, and you want that for explosives.

Second:
When you mix then together, use a tiny bit of alcohol (alcohol dries faster = better burn time) to wet the powder so that it forms very lose lumps. Then move that through a strainer with bigger holes to granulate it into bigger chunks. That is necessary for bigger explosions. Leaving it a powder it will burn slowly like in this video and that is way to slow for proper black powder.

Hey Grant;

For a future project, you can take some cotton string, Mix the powder with dextrin and wet with a 25/75 rubbing alcohol/water mix, and coat the string with the wet powder to make a simple black match fuse (scrape excess powder off before it dries). This gives you a VERY simple fuse with a burn rate around 1 inch per second. To speed it up, you can then wrap the black match in loose paper or even scotch/painter's tape, giving you quick match which burns very very rapidly (feet per second). I prefer paper because you can rip a foot or two of paper off, giving you 10-20 seconds of predictible slow burn, followed by a rapid combustion to whatever you've put your fuse into.

Might be worth trying. Cheers!

Grant, would you consider making flash cotton or "guncotton"? It usually requires 50% Nitric acid and 50% Sulfuric acid, and you soak pure cotton in it and then wash it in water to make sure it is a neutral PH. Once you burn it after it dries, it quickly ignites and burns smokeless and ashless, and very quickly. Most videos only do small patches, but I have never seen anything larger, such as a t-shirt, turned into flash cotton and burned. Many places list more steps than that, but a quick Google search can change that. Just an idea that I hope you would consider.

Sorry, not even close.  Actual black powder is milled wet, then spread out, granulated and dried.  You will be astounded at the change in burn rate.  It's not so much the particle size as the fact the oxidizer is still in crystals.  Wet milling forces the oxidizer into he pores on the tiny charcoal powder, and the sulfur provides partcle-to-particle ignition.   Fwiw, I've been doing this stuff since 1976,

My Personal Recipe for Black Powder
(much more explosive)
75 g Kno3
15 g Charcoal
10 g Sulfur
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Step 1.
Mix ingredients and put in ball mill for 5 hours
Step 2.
Add 50/50 water/alcohol mix until granulated and sticks to stirring rod
Step 3.
Put wet material into Mason jar for 3 days
Step 4.
Take out wet material and lay on flat surface to dry
Step 5.
Put dry mixture in ball mill for 5 hours.
Step 6.
Stir in 5g of dextrin
Step 7.
Add water/alcohal mix until granulated
Step 8.
Press through strainer and leave to dry

That's a really slow burning powder, and it's not because it's in open air: unlike modern smokeless powders, black powder does not require compression to achieve a specific burn rate. If that were firearms grade FFF or FFFF black powder all you would have seen was an incredibly large flash, like a camera flash going off.

The speed it burns in open air is the same speed it'll burn in a confined space, which is one reason black powder is regulated as an "explosive" and modern smokeless powder is only regulated as "flammable". There are several other processes black powder generally goes under to increase the burn rate, the most significant being mixing it with water. It seems counter-intuitive, but saturating the powder with water and then drying drastically increases the burn rate as it dissolves the potassium nitrate salts (the oxidizer in this mixture) into the water and then, as it's dried, the potassium nitrate is deposited in all the microscopic pores in the charcoal particles.

Hey Grant,
The way I used to make fuses was to take a piece of clear Scotch tape and pull off whatever length I needed based on how fast or slow of a lead time I needed. next take the lid off of the container housing the gunpowder and slowly lower the tape into the container as you gently shake the container left to right. the gunpowder will coat the tape as it's being lowered in and will leave just enough gunpowder on the tape for it to burn very nicely, but at a slow rate giving you plenty time to move away from the explosion. it's much easier than making the fuses like you've done in the past. try it sometime with this powder you've made. No, Blackpowder does not change all that much under pressure. It should burn extremely fast even in atmospheric pressure conditions. Hey Grant, a tip to make your black powder burn faster: mix the powder in water in a 1 part powder 2 parts water ratio. Make sure that the powder is completely wet and slushy. Excess water is fine. Now let it dry completely and grind it up again. This will make the molecules in the 3 substances marry with each other much better and should produce a faster burn.
